GPUDevice.summary: The GPUDevice interface of the {{domxref("WebGPU API", "WebGPU API", "", "nocode")}} represents a logical GPU device. This is the main interface through which the majority of WebGPU functionality is accessed.

remarks.para: A GPUDevice object is requested using the method.

GPUDeviceAdapterInfo.summary:
The adapterInfo read-only property of the
interface returns a object containing identifying information about the device's originating adapter.

GPUDeviceCreateBindGroup.summary:
The createBindGroup() method of the
interface creates a based on a that defines a set of resources to be bound together in a group and how those resources are used in shader stages.

GPUDeviceCreateBindGroupLayout.summary:
The createBindGroupLayout() method of the
interface creates a that defines the structure and purpose of related GPU resources such as buffers that will be used in a pipeline, and is used as a template when creating s.

GPUDeviceCreateBuffer.summary:
The createBuffer() method of the
interface creates a in which to store raw data to use in GPU operations.

GPUDeviceCreateCommandEncoder.summary:
The createCommandEncoder() method of the
interface creates a , used to encode commands to be issued to the GPU.

GPUDeviceCreateComputePipeline.summary:
The createComputePipeline() method of the
interface creates a that can control the compute shader stage and be used in a .

GPUDeviceCreateComputePipelineAsync.summary:
The createComputePipelineAsync() method of the
interface returns a {{jsxref("Promise")}} that fulfills with a , which can control the compute shader stage and be used in a , once the pipeline can be used without any stalling.

blockquote.para: It is generally preferable to use this method over whenever possible, as it prevents blocking of GPU operation execution on pipeline compilation.

GPUDeviceCreateComputePipelineAsync.returns: A {{jsxref("Promise")}} that fulfills with a object instance when the created pipeline is ready to be used without additional delay.

GPUDeviceCreatePipelineLayout.summary:
The createPipelineLayout() method of the
interface creates a that defines the s used by a pipeline. s used with the pipeline during command encoding must have compatible s.

GPUDeviceCreateQuerySet.summary:
The createQuerySet() method of the
interface creates a that can be used to record the results of queries on passes, such as occlusion or timestamp queries.

GPUDeviceCreateRenderBundleEncoder.summary:
The createRenderBundleEncoder() method of the
interface creates a that can be used to pre-record bundles of commands. These can be reused in s via the method, as many times as required.

GPUDeviceCreateRenderPipeline.summary:
The createRenderPipeline() method of the
interface creates a that can control the vertex and fragment shader stages and be used in a or .

GPUDeviceCreateRenderPipelineAsync.summary:
The createRenderPipelineAsync() method of the
interface returns a {{jsxref("Promise")}} that fulfills with a , which can control the vertex and fragment shader stages and be used in a or , once the pipeline can be used without any stalling.

blockquote.para: It is generally preferable to use this method over whenever possible, as it prevents blocking of GPU operation execution on pipeline compilation.

GPUDeviceCreateRenderPipelineAsync.returns: A {{jsxref("Promise")}} that fulfills with a object instance when the created pipeline is ready to be used without additional delay.

GPUDeviceCreateSampler.summary:
The createSampler() method of the
interface creates a , which controls how shaders transform and filter texture resource data.

GPUDeviceCreateShaderModule.summary:
The createShaderModule() method of the
interface creates a from a string of WGSL source code.

remarks.para:
-The WebGPU API
-The WebGPU Shading Language specification

GPUDeviceCreateTexture.summary:
The createTexture() method of the
interface creates a in which to store 1D, 2D, or 3D arrays of data, such as images, to use in GPU rendering operations.

GPUDeviceDestroy.summary:
The destroy() method of the
interface destroys the device, preventing further operations on it.

GPUDeviceFeatures.summary:
The features read-only property of the
interface returns a object that describes additional functionality supported by the device. Only features requested during the creation of the device (i.e., when is called) are included.

blockquote.para: Not all features will be available to WebGPU in all browsers that support it, even if the features are supported by the underlying hardware. See for more details.

GPUDeviceFeatures.value: A object instance. This is a setlike object.

GPUDeviceImportExternalTexture.summary:
The importExternalTexture() method of the
interface takes an or a object as an input and returns a wrapper object containing a snapshot of the video that can be used as a frame in GPU rendering operations.
GPUDeviceImportExternalTexture.returns: A object instance.Note that the moment when the object expires (is destroyed) depends on what its source is:

GPUDeviceLabel.summary:
The label read-only property of the
interface is a string providing a label that can be used to identify the object, for example in messages or console warnings.
GPUDeviceLabel.value: A string. If no label value has previously been set, getting the label returns an empty string.

GPUDeviceLimits.summary:
The limits read-only property of the
interface returns a object that describes the limits supported by the device. All limit values will be included, and the limits requested during the creation of the device (i.e., when is called) will be reflected in those values.

blockquote.para: Not all limits will be reported as expected, even if they are supported by the underlying hardware. See for more details.

GPUDeviceLost.summary:
The lost read-only property of the
interface contains a {{jsxref("Promise")}} that remains pending throughout the device's lifetime and resolves with a object when the device is lost.

remarks.para: will never return null, and it will reject only if the request is invalid, i.e., it exceeds the capabilities of the . If a valid device request can't be fulfilled for some reason however it may resolve to a device that has already been lost. Additionally, devices can be lost at any time after creation for a variety of reasons (such as browser resource management or driver updates), so it's a good idea to always handle lost devices gracefully.

Many causes for lost devices are transient, so you should try getting a new device once a previous one has been lost unless the loss was caused by the application intentionally destroying the device (i.e., with ). Note that any WebGPU resources created with a previous device (buffers, textures, etc.) will need to be re-created with the new one.

blockquote.para: Also bear in mind that a GPUAdapter may become unavailable, e.g., if the physical GPU is unplugged from the system or disabled to save power. From then on, the adapter can no longer return valid devices, and will always return already-lost devices.

GPUDeviceLost.value: A promise that resolves with a object when the device is lost.

GPUDevicePopErrorScope.summary:
The popErrorScope() method of the
interface pops an existing GPU error scope from the error scope stack (originally pushed using ) and returns a {{jsxref("Promise")}} that resolves to an object describing the first error captured in the scope, or null if no error occurred.
GPUDevicePopErrorScope.returns: A that resolves to an object describing the first error captured in the scope. This can be of type:If no error occurred, it resolves to null.

GPUDevicePushErrorScope.summary:
The pushErrorScope() method of the
interface pushes a new GPU error scope onto the device's error scope stack, allowing you to capture errors of a particular type.

remarks.para: Once you are done capturing errors, you can end capture by invoking . This pops the scope from the stack and returns a {{jsxref("Promise")}} that resolves to an object describing the first error captured in the scope, or null if no errors were captured.

GPUDeviceQueue.summary:
The queue read-only property of the
interface returns the primary for the device.

GPUDeviceUncapturederror.summary: The uncapturederror event of the interface is fired when an error is thrown that has not been observed by a GPU error scope, to provide a way to report unexpected errors.

remarks.para: Known error cases should be handled using and .
